content.raw:
When I try to run this on a sample Ramses dataset (output_00080) provided in the yt data page, I get a failure.


```
#!python

import yt
ds = yt.load('output_00080/info_00080.txt')
ds.print_stats()

```


```
#!python

IndexError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/mods.pyc in <module>()
----> 1 ds.print_stats()

    317     def root_only(*args, **kwargs):
    318         if not parallel_capable:
--> 319             return func(*args, **kwargs)
    320         comm = _get_comm(args)
    321         rv = None

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/static_output.pyc in print_stats(self)
    357     @parallel_root_only
    358     def print_stats(self):
--> 359         self.index.print_stats()
    360
    361     @property

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/frontends/ramses/data_structures.pyc in print_stats(self)
    480
    481     def print_stats(self):
--> 482         self._initialize_level_stats()
    483         """
    484         Prints out (stdout) relevant information about the simulation

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/frontends/ramses/data_structures.pyc in _initialize_level_stats(self)
    477             self.level_stats[level+1]['numcells']=2**(level*self.dataset.dimensionality)
    478         for level in range(self.max_level+1):
--> 479             self.level_stats[level+self.dataset.min_level+1]['numcells'] = levels[level]
    480
    481     def print_stats(self):

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/records.pyc in __getitem__(self, indx)
```

content.html:
When I try to run this on a sample Ramses dataset (output_00080) provided in the yt data page, I get a failure.

import yt
ds = yt.load('output_00080/info_00080.txt')
ds.print_stats()

IndexError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/mods.pyc in <module>()
----> 1 ds.print_stats()

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/utilities/parallel_tools/parallel_analysis_interface.pyc in root_only(*args, **kwargs)
    317     def root_only(*args, **kwargs):
    318         if not parallel_capable:
--> 319             return func(*args, **kwargs)
    320         comm = _get_comm(args)
    321         rv = None

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/static_output.pyc in print_stats(self)
    357     @parallel_root_only
    358     def print_stats(self):
--> 359         self.index.print_stats()
    360
    361     @property

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/frontends/ramses/data_structures.pyc in print_stats(self)
    480
    481     def print_stats(self):
--> 482         self._initialize_level_stats()
    483         """
    484         Prints out (stdout) relevant information about the simulation

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/frontends/ramses/data_structures.pyc in _initialize_level_stats(self)
    477             self.level_stats[level+1]['numcells']=2**(level*self.dataset.dimensionality)
    478         for level in range(self.max_level+1):
--> 479             self.level_stats[level+self.dataset.min_level+1]['numcells'] = levels[level]
    480
    481     def print_stats(self):

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/records.pyc in __getitem__(self, indx)
    456

--> 458         obj = ndarray.__getitem__(self, indx)
    459         if (isinstance(obj, ndarray) and obj.dtype.isbuiltin):
    460             return obj.view(ndarray)

content.raw: I've tested this out on several of the ramses outputs from the sample data page.  It seems to work well, except it crashes when you use it on a DM-only run (e.g. output_00101).  Perhaps providing a note in the docstrings about not using on DM-only runs, as well as a check to see if the simulation has gas present and raise a helpful exception if it doesn't?  Other than that and the extra print statement I've noted below, I think this is good.  Thanks for the contribution, @RicardaBeckmann !
content.html: I've tested this out on several of the ramses outputs from the sample data page. It seems to work well, except it crashes when you use it on a DM-only run (e.g. output_00101). Perhaps providing a note in the docstrings about not using on DM-only runs, as well as a check to see if the simulation has gas present and raise a helpful exception if it doesn't? Other than that and the extra print statement I've noted below, I think this is good. Thanks for the contribution, Ricarda Beckmann !

content.raw: Maybe it's an easy fix for pure-DM runs.  What's the traceback?
content.html: Maybe it's an easy fix for pure-DM runs. What's the traceback?

content.raw:
Yeah, it should be easy.  One could just look in the derived_field_list to see if there are any ('gas', ...) fields, right?

The failure is that it cannot find the `hydro` files, so that could be a check too.

content.html:
Yeah, it should be easy. One could just look in the derived_field_list to see if there are any ('gas', ...) fields, right?

The failure is that it cannot find the hydro files, so that could be a check too.

Full traceback:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/mods.pyc in <module>()
----> 1 ds.print_stats()

    317     def root_only(*args, **kwargs):
    318         if not parallel_capable:
--> 319             return func(*args, **kwargs)
    320         comm = _get_comm(args)
    321         rv = None

/Users/chummels/src/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/static_output.pyc in print_stats(self)

    358     def print_stats(self):
--> 359         self.index.print_stats()
    360
    361     @property

--> 482         self._initialize_level_stats()
    483         """

    467

--> 469         levels=sum([dom.level_count for dom in self.domains])

    471                 'formats':['Int64']*2}

content.raw:
Thanks for that note, I fixed that issue (by checking for fluid fields, as suggested) Instead of crashing, it now prints a message that states: "This function is not implemented for DM only runs" Does that sound too nasty? At least it's not an error message.

I also created a small DM only run to add to the yt sample data set. How do I actually do that? Here is the link:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/45674324/cosmo_DMonly.tar.gz
It's a small (10 Mpc)  DM only cosmology run that unzips to 331 MB. The initial conditions are done with MUSIC.

We can help with that.

content.raw: So the issue with pure DM runs is that we infer the structure of the AMR octree from the `hydro` files. Is this information also present in the `part`, `grav`, or `amr` files? Maybe we just need to implement that logic in a more general way. I don't know anything about the Ramses output format, so my question might be ill-posed.
content.html: So the issue with pure DM runs is that we infer the structure of the AMR octree from the hydro files. Is this information also present in the part, grav, or amr files? Maybe we just need to implement that logic in a more general way. I don't know anything about the Ramses output format, so my question might be ill-posed.

content.raw: In particular, it looks like `hydro_offset` gets the `level_count`. Interestingly, we seem to have another way of getting `level_count` for pure DM runs, since `ds.index.max_level` is defined for the `output_00101` dataset.
content.html: In particular, it looks like hydro_offset gets the level_count. Interestingly, we seem to have another way of getting level_count for pure DM runs, since ds.index.max_level is defined for the output_00101 dataset.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: The AMR structure is contained in the "amr" files. The "hydro" files only contain information about the hydro variables (gas density, velocity, pressure, metallicity, magnetic fields, ionisation state, etc, etc). "grav" should have a similar structure to "hydro" as both are attached to the AMR grid. The only file that is guaranteed to exist in every RAMSES simulation (other than the "info" file) is the "amr" file(s), although you will have either/both of "hydro"/"part" as well.
content.html: The AMR structure is contained in the "amr" files. The "hydro" files only contain information about the hydro variables (gas density, velocity, pressure, metallicity, magnetic fields, ionisation state, etc, etc). "grav" should have a similar structure to "hydro" as both are attached to the AMR grid. The only file that is guaranteed to exist in every RAMSES simulation (other than the "info" file) is the "amr" file(s), although you will have either/both of "hydro"/"part" as well.

content.raw: Thanks for the help. I instead decided to edit the descriptions of the existing Ramses datasets on the website, to make it a bit clearer that one is DM only and the other one includes Stars, DM and gas. I think the ones we have at the minute cover most situations already.
content.html: Thanks for the help. I instead decided to edit the descriptions of the existing Ramses datasets on the website, to make it a bit clearer that one is DM only and the other one includes Stars, DM and gas. I think the ones we have at the minute cover most situations already.

content.raw:
Nathan, that's an interesting point. It should definitely be possible, for both hydro and DM only runs, to define it from the AMR files. I was actually thinking of at some point tackling the issue that ('index','grid_levels') and similar fields are broken as well. I sometimes want to plot refinement levels so that's a functionality I actually need.

I'm not entirely certain how much work that is going to be yet so I'd like to leave it to a future pull request.

I was actually thinking of at some point tackling the issue that ('index','grid_levels') and similar fields are broken as well. I sometimes want to plot refinement levels so that's a functionality I actually need.

I'm not entirely certain how much work that is going to be yet so I'd like to leave it to a future pull request.

content.raw: Sounds good to me!
content.html: Sounds good to me!

description:
Hi everybody,

I wrote a print_stats function for RAMSES that looks fairly similar to the one for Enzo shown in the Quickstart notebooks. When I first started with yt I was a little confused that it didn't exist.

It looks pretty much the same as the one for Enzo and similar codes, except that I skipped the #Grids column because I find it to not be very useful for Octree codes.

I considered writing one for all codes using the octree_geometry_handler but that turned out to be more difficult than anticipated as all codes seem to handle their internal structural information very differently.

Let me know what you think,
Ricarda


* added print_stats to oct_geometry_handler

* moved print_stats function into ramses file directly

* fixed a bug in print_stats for RAMSES

* sorted out some cosmetic difference in file
